title: Grateful and confused
content:
*I‚Äôm editing this review to say: if you have experience with an eating disorder maybe avoid the episode with Caitlin Moran or proceed with caution. There are many details that can be very triggering and unhelpful, as well, not HAES informed (the O word is used).*

I genuinely think Jameela is doing great work and I‚Äôm grateful for her public self reflection and vulnerability. I hope she continues to role model  how to give ourselves permission to learn and unlearn as fast or slowly as we need. I also think she speaks to an AMAZING range of incredible people. With that said, as someone who is deeply concerned about, and recovering from diet culture and deep into learning about dismantling it, I‚Äôm disappointed that I get frustrated with the ways she still seems to miss the mark. I think it‚Äôs okay to say this because it‚Äôs different when talking about someone you know versus someone with a huge platform who talks about this stuff intentionally using that platform. Maybe I‚Äôm being too picky but it‚Äôs these things that make it hard for me to listen sometimes: examples: when interviewing Aubrey (Yrfatfriend), she interjects to share about how she can relate and talks about her chubbiness in childhood; about how she loved her tummy and would intentionally show off her ‚Äúfood baby‚Äù or ‚Äústick it out‚Äù. The thing is, I wanted to hear about Audrey‚Äôs experience not about how their experiences are similar. Because they *are* different and that was Aubrey‚Äôs point. Someone who can actually ‚Äústick their tummy out‚Äù or show a food baby is not the same as the kind of fatness that gets oppressed. Many people cannot choose when they want or don‚Äôt want to stick their bellies out and a ‚Äúfood baby‚Äù only really shows when your thin enough that eating will make a difference in the shape and size of your belly. This is just an example but instead of always relating it back to her moments of undoubtedly difficult but normal weight gain I wish we could just embrace the fat experience. Next, the ads. Why are they all wellness ads? And I don‚Äôt mean the kind of wellness that is counter to ‚Äúwellness‚Äù and diet culture. She says she takes Ritual vitamins because they are *clean* (this is a harmfully ambiguous and notorious ‚Äúwellness‚Äù culture term that falsely demonizes large groups of foods and harmful for those with orthorexia) also she says she takes them because she is lazy and isn‚Äôt always a nutritional expert. I know she‚Äôs being silly but its actually a ‚Äúwellness‚Äù culture marketing technique (pulled from diet industry) to play on our vulnerability of not being nutritional experts to get us to spend money on expensive vitamins that we‚Äôre probably already getting from our food. They target those who can already afford to get their needs met through food but often don‚Äôt because elite wellness culture preaches restriction.
